issues.title: Option to provide only schema-url?
issues.author: c2bo
issues.body:
I just finished my first read of the draft and it feels like the overall concept makes a lot of sense as a general approach for credential type metadata! The main thing I was wondering about when reading the draft was if this is really necessary for every credential or if sometimes only providing some kind of schema information would be sufficient.

Do you think it makes sense to also allow an option where the `vct` claim directly references a schema (perhaps including the integrity information)? This could be a lightweight version where the credential issuer will not provide additional metadata but wants to convey at least the schema (most likely an external URL).

comments.author: danielfett
comments.body: Just for clarification, by schema you mean the JSON schema?

comments.author: c2bo
comments.body:
> Just for clarification, by schema you mean the JSON schema?

Yes. I am wondering if we always need/want the full metadata or if sometimes just a JSON schema reference would be fine. Basically a subset of information that does not require some kind of .well-known ressource.

issues.title: Improvements to example
issues.author: jogu
issues.body:
A couple of things I spotted about the example:

1. I think it's defining a credential for all Betelgeuse universities, but the example logo implies it's only for a single university: "https://exampleuniversity.com/public/logo.png" - "https://betelgeuse.example.com/education-logo.png" might be better
2. There isn't a logo defined for de-DE, which seems inconsistent with Section 7 ("Display Metadata") as there are claim display names defined for de-DE: "The object MUST contain a property for each language that is supported by the type"
3. The vct of "https://betelgeuse.example.com/identity_credential" - I'm not sure 'identity_credential' is a good description for the contents, maybe "https://betelgeuse.example.com/degree_credential" is better (I think it's not an identity credential with an optional degree, because if it was the name would be authoritative and it would probably allow multiple degrees to be listed)
4. The formatting is a bit messed up in the rendered example in general as there's a mixture of spaces/tabs

comments.author: c2bo
comments.body: I've played around with some of the options and I was surprised how well the array of strings seemed to work when traversing a nested struct (fits quite nicely with a stack remembering the parent names). The only thing that just feels wrong to me is the null to signal all elements of an array  but not sure what the cleanest/best option would be.

I've read this bit several times and it just doesn't seem right (i.e., "object MAY contain an object" wouldn't be valid JSON and I don't think is what you are trying to say anyway, and with "property value MUST be an object" - there's no property value to be an object at this level). Here is an attempt to adjust the words to say what I think you were trying to say:

```suggestion
The array MAY contain an object for each claim that is supported by the type.
Each object contains the following properties:
```
I wonder if it might be worthwhile to add one with just `["degrees"]` or `["address"]` to give an example of selecting and providing metadata about the higher level claim of a nested claim structure?

The possible plural on "array(s)" here jumped out at me and gave pause. I wonder putting a limit of a max of one `null` element per path array would be a useful simplification (and acceptable limitation)?

This example is somewhat different than the others and not high on the list of the parts of a claims structure that I imagine will be selected to provide metadata about. I dunno but wonder if having it detracts more than helps. Just a thought...

Something like
- `["address"]`: The claim `address` with its sub-claims as the value is selected.

```suggestion
- `["address"]`: The claim `address` with its sub-claims as the value is selected.
- `["address", "street_address"]`: The claim `street_address` with the value
  `42 Market Street` is selected.
```
It shows a corner case we either need to discuss or prohibit. Not sure if this will actually be useful though.

I think that something like "select the names of the courses required for all degrees earned" or something like that is a valid use case. I'm also not sure whether such a limitation would make the implementation significantly easier.
Done!
Yeah, but rather than discuss or prohibit I guess I'm suggesting just don't call attention to :) at least for right now

I'm also not sure to be honest but it seemed like potentially useful simplification. The "something like ... or something like" case you have doesn't seem invalid but I just don't know if it's necessary either. I'm honestly not sure though so feel free to resolve this comment having considered and dismissed the idea :)
